Submodules¶

forecaster.strategy.allocation module¶

Provides classes for determining asset allocation.

class forecaster.strategy.allocation.AllocationStrategy(strategy, target, min_equity=0, max_equity=1, standard_retirement_age=65, risk_transition_period=20, adjust_for_retirement_plan=True)[source]¶

Bases: forecaster.strategy.base.Strategy

Generates an asset allocation for a point in time. Callable.

strategy¶

Either a string corresponding to a particular strategy or an instance of the strategy itself. See strategies for acceptable keys.

Type

str, func

strategies¶

{str, func} pairs where each key identifies a strategy (in human-readable text) and each value is a function with the same arguments and return value as transactions(). See its documentation for more info.

Acceptable keys include:

  • “n-age”

  • “Transition to constant”

Type

dict

min_equity¶

The minimum percentage of a portfolio that may be invested in equities. (All non-equity investments are included in fixed_income)

Type

Decimal

max_equity¶

The maximum percentage of a portfolio that may be invested in equities.

Type

Decimal

target¶

A target value used by strategies to affect their behaviour.

For example, for the n-age strategy, this is the value n (e.g. target=100 -> 100-age).

For the Transition to constant strategy, this is the percentage of equities to transition to (e.g. for Transition to 50-50, use Decimal(‘0.5’))

Type

Decimal

standard_retirement_age¶

The typical retirement age used in retirement planning.

This is used if adjust_for_retirement_plan is False, otherwise the actual (or estimated) retirement age for the person is used.

Type

int

risk_transition_period¶

The period of time over which the Transition to constant strategy transitions.

For example, if set to 20, the strategy will transition from max_equity to transition_strategy_target over 20 years, ending on the retirement date.

Type

int

adjust_for_retirement_plan¶

If True, the allocation will be adjusted to increase risk for later retirement or decrease risk for later retirement. If False, the standard retirement age will be used.

Type

bool

Parameters

  • age (int) – The current age of the plannee.

  • retirement_age (int) – The (estimated) retirement age of the plannee.

Returns

A namedtuple where each member is the percentage of a portfolio that is made up of the named asset class.

Allocations of the members sum to 1 (e.g. Decimal(0.03 means 3%).

Return type

AssetAllocation

Raises

ValueError – min_equity greater than max_equity.

__call__(age, *args, retirement_age=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns a dict of {account, Money} pairs.

__init__(strategy, target, min_equity=0, max_equity=1, standard_retirement_age=65, risk_transition_period=20, adjust_for_retirement_plan=True)[source]¶

Constructor for AllocationStrategy.

rate_function(person, scenario)[source]¶

A rate function usable by Person or Account objects.

Parameters

  • person (Person) – A person. The method builds a portfolio for the person based on this object’s allocation strategy (in particular, based on the person’s age and/or projected retirement date).

  • scenario (Scenario) – A Scenario providing information on returns on investment for stocks, bonds, etc.

Returns

An object callable with the form rate_function(year) -> Decimal that provides a rate of return for a given year based on the person’s age and the investment returns for various asset classes provided by scenario.

strategies = {'Transition to constant': <function AllocationStrategy.strategy_transition_to_const>, 'n-age': <function AllocationStrategy.strategy_n_minus_age>}
strategy_n_minus_age(age, *args, retirement_age=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used for 100-age, 110-age, 125-age, etc. strategies.

strategy_transition_to_const(age, *args, retirement_age=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used for Transition to 50-50, Transition to 70-30, etc.

forecaster.strategy.base module¶

A module that provides generic Strategy infrastructure.

In particular, the modules offers a Strategy base class and a complementary @strategy_method decorator for use by subclasses.

class forecaster.strategy.base.Strategy(strategy)[source]¶

Bases: object

An abstract callable class for determining a strategy.

strategy¶

Either a string corresponding to a particular strategy or an instance of the strategy itself. See strategies for acceptable keys.

Type

str, func

strategies¶

{str, func} pairs where each key identifies a strategy (in human-readable text) and each value is a function. All functions have the same call signature and return value; this is the call signature of the Strategy object.

See each subclass’s documentation for more information on the call signature for the subclass.

Type

dict

__call__(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Makes the Strategy object callable.

strategies = {}
class forecaster.strategy.base.StrategyType(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: type

A metaclass for Strategy classes.

This metaclass inspects the class for any @strategy(key)-decorated methods and generates a strategies dict of {key, func} pairs. This strategies dict is then accessible from the class interface.

NOTE: One side-effect of this approach is that strategy methods are collected only once, at definition time. If you want to add a strategy to a class later, you’ll need to manually add it to the subclass’s strategies dict. TODO: Add static class methods to Strategy to register/unregister strategy methods? (consider using signature (func [, key]))

forecaster.strategy.base.strategy_method(key)[source]¶

A decorator for strategy methods, used by Strategy subclasses

Methods decorated with this decorator will be automatically added to the dict strategies, which is an attribute of the subclass. This happens at class definition time; you need to manually register strategy methods that are added dynamically.

Example:

class ExampleStrategy(Strategy):
    @strategy_method('method key')
    def _strategy_method(self):
        return

ExampleStrategy.strategies['method key'] ==             ExampleStrategy._strategy_method

forecaster.strategy.gross_transaction module¶

Provides classes for determining the total sum of transactions.

class forecaster.strategy.gross_transaction.LivingExpensesStrategy(strategy, base_amount=0, rate=0, inflation_adjust=None)[source]¶

Bases: forecaster.strategy.base.Strategy

Determines annual living expenses.

This class is callable. Its call signature has this form:

obj(year, refund, other_contribution, net_income, gross_income)

Arguments may be omitted if the selected strategy does not require it; otherwise, an error is raised. All arguments are keyword arguments.

strategy¶

A string corresponding to a particular contribution strategy. See strategies for acceptable keys.

Type

str

strategies¶

{str, func} pairs where each key identifies a strategy (in human-readable text) and each value is a function with the same arguments and return value as gross_contribution(). See its documentation for more info.

Acceptable keys include:

  • “Constant contribution”

  • “Constant living expenses”

  • “Percentage of gross income”

  • “Percentage of net income”

  • “Percentage of principal at retirement”

  • “Percentage of gross income at retirement”

  • “Percentage of net income at retirement”

Type

dict

base_amount¶

A user-supplied amount of money, used in some strategies as a baseline for contributions.

Type

Money

rate¶

A user-supplied contribution rate. Must be a percentage (e.g. Decimal(‘0.03’) means 3%).

Type

Decimal

refund_reinvestment_rate¶

The percentage of each tax refund that is reinvested in the year it’s received.

Type

Decimal

inflation_adjust¶

If provided, base_amount is interpreted as a real (i.e. inflation-adjusted) currency value.

This callable object will be called as inflation_adjust(year[, base_year]) to receive the inflation-adjustment factor between real and nominal values for that year (relative to base_year, if provided).

Optional. If not provided, base_amount is not inflation_adjusted.

Type

callable

Parameters

people (set[Person]) – The plannees (one or more people) with at least net_income and gross_income attributes.

Returns

A Money object corresponding to the living expenses incurred by the plannees for the year.

Raises

ValueError – A required value was not provided for the given strategy.

__call__(*args, people=None, year=None, retirement_year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns the living expenses for the year.

__init__(strategy, base_amount=0, rate=0, inflation_adjust=None)[source]¶

strategies = {'Constant contribution': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_const_contribution>, 'Constant living expenses': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_const_living_expenses>, 'Percentage of earnings growth': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_percent_over_base>, 'Percentage of gross income': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_gross_percent>, 'Percentage of gross income at retirement': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_gross_percent_ret>, 'Percentage of net income': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_net_percent>, 'Percentage of net income at retirement': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_net_percent_ret>, 'Percentage of principal at retirement': <function LivingExpensesStrategy.strategy_principal_percent_ret>}
strategy_const_contribution(people, *args, year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Contribute a constant (real) amount and live off the rest.

strategy_const_living_expenses(*args, year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Living expenses remain constant, in real terms.

strategy_gross_percent(people, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Live off a percentage of gross income.

strategy_gross_percent_ret(people, retirement_year, *args, year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Live off a percentage of net income.

strategy_net_percent_ret(people, retirement_year, *args, year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Withdraw a percentage of max. net income (as of retirement).

strategy_percent_over_base(people, *args, year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Live off a base amount plus a percentage of earnings above it.

strategy_principal_percent_ret(accounts, retirement_year, *args, year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Withdraw a percentage of principal (as of retirement).

class forecaster.strategy.gross_transaction.LivingExpensesStrategySchedule(working, retirement, minimum=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Determines living expenses while working and retired.

This class is callable, like LivingExpensesStrategy, and accepts all of the same arguments when called.

Objects of this class wrap LivingExpensesStrategy objects - one for working life and one for retirement. The appropriate object is called depending on the current year.

An additional LivingExpensesStrategy may also, optionally, be provided as a minimum level of expenses. This lets you avoid perverse situations where annual fluctuations in income or assets reduce living expenses unacceptably low.

working¶

The strategy to use during the plannees’ working life.

Type

LivingExpensesStrategy

retirement¶

The strategy to use during the plannees’ retirement.

Type

LivingExpensesStrategy

minimum¶

Provides a minimum living standard that must be met. Optional. May be a LivingExpensesStrategySchedule if you want to use different minima for working and retired phases of life.

Type

LivingExpensesStrategy

Parameters

  • year (int) – The current year.

  • retirement_year (int) – The plannees’ retirement year. Optional; if not provided, it’s assumed that the plannees are still working.

Returns

A Money object corresponding to the living expenses incurred by the plannees for the year.

Raises

ValueError – A required value was not provided for the given strategy.

__call__(*args, year=None, retirement_year=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns the living expenses for the year.

__init__(working, retirement, minimum=None)[source]¶

Inits LivingExpensesStrategySchedule.

Module contents¶

A package for providing user-definable behaviour (“strategies”).
